title: How to Dry Edible Seeds

steps.headline: Select the pumpkin seeds.
steps.description: You can use ones from your garden or from a pumpkin you've bought from the farmers market.

steps.headline: Cut the top off the pumpkin.
Scoop the seeds out of the pumpkin.
Remove any of the fleshy parts of the pumpkin that is attached to the seeds.
steps.description: This can be done by hand, sometimes with the help of a paring knife.

steps.headline: Wash the seeds.
steps.description: Put the pumpkin seeds in a colander and rinse them using cool or warm water.

steps.headline: Put the pumpkin seeds on paper towels and blot them dry.
steps.description: Be sure to remove any flesh or debris from the pumpkin that has been left behind. If this isn't removed, the seeds can rot.

steps.headline: Spread the pumpkin seeds on a cookie or baking sheet.
Dry the pumpkin seeds in a dehydrator at 115 to 120 °F (46 to 49 °C) for one to two hours.
steps.description: Or, dry them in an oven, on warm, for three to four hours. Stir them frequently to avoid scorching.

steps.headline: Remove the dried pumpkin seeds from the heat once they are thoroughly dry.
steps.description: Store them in an airtight container and use within three to six months of drying. They can be eaten raw, roasted or added to dishes. To roast, take dried pumpkin seeds, toss with oil and/or salt and roast in a preheated oven at 250 °F (121 °C) for 10 to 15 minutes.

steps.headline: Choose a suitable variety to dry at home.
steps.description: The best varieties are Japanese hull-less, hybrid South American mushroom, cream puff hybrid, white cloud and dynamite.

steps.headline: Air dry in place.
steps.description: Simply leave the ears of popcorn on the stalks until the kernels are well-dried.

steps.headline: Air dry in the house.
steps.description: Harvested ears of corn can be air-dried at a temperature below 130 °F (54 °C). When the kernels are dry, remove them from the ears and package. Dried corn will appear shriveled. Pop a few kernels to test. Popcorn will dry down to about 10 percent moisture. No pretreatment is necessary.

steps.headline: Wrap the flower of the sunflower plant in cheesecloth.
steps.description: The seeds are usually left on the flower to dry. Wrapping allows you to catch the seeds while preventing the birds from eating them.

steps.headline: Dry off the plant.
steps.description: Sunflower seeds may be dried in the sun or in a dehydrator at 100 °F (38 °C). Higher temperatures affect the flavor, so keep it low.

steps.headline: Roast the seeds.
steps.description: When the seeds are dried, they can be roasted in a shallow pan at 300 °F (149 °C) for 10 to 15 minutes. See further How to dry and season raw sunflower seeds.

text: Drying pumpkin seeds Select the pumpkin seeds. You can use ones from your garden or from a pumpkin you've bought from the farmers market. Cut the top off the pumpkin. Discard it. Scoop the seeds out of the pumpkin.  Remove any of the fleshy parts of the pumpkin that is attached to the seeds. This can be done by hand, sometimes with the help of a paring knife. Wash the seeds. Put the pumpkin seeds in a colander and rinse them using cool or warm water. Put the pumpkin seeds on paper towels and blot them dry. Be sure to remove any flesh or debris from the pumpkin that has been left behind. If this isn't removed, the seeds can rot. Spread the pumpkin seeds on a cookie or baking sheet.  Dry the pumpkin seeds in a dehydrator at 115 to 120 °F (46 to 49 °C) for one to two hours. Or, dry them in an oven, on warm, for three to four hours. Stir them frequently to avoid scorching. Remove the dried pumpkin seeds from the heat once they are thoroughly dry. Store them in an airtight container and use within three to six months of drying. They can be eaten raw, roasted or added to dishes. To roast, take dried pumpkin seeds, toss with oil and/or salt and roast in a preheated oven at 250 °F (121 °C) for 10 to 15 minutes. Finished.  Drying popcorn seeds (kernels) Choose a suitable variety to dry at home. The best varieties are Japanese hull-less, hybrid South American mushroom, cream puff hybrid, white cloud and dynamite. Air dry in place. Simply leave the ears of popcorn on the stalks until the kernels are well-dried. Air dry in the house. Harvested ears of corn can be air-dried at a temperature below 130 °F (54 °C). When the kernels are dry, remove them from the ears and package. Dried corn will appear shriveled. Pop a few kernels to test. Popcorn will dry down to about 10 percent moisture. No pretreatment is necessary. Drying sunflower seeds Wrap the flower of the sunflower plant in cheesecloth. The seeds are usually left on the flower to dry. Wrapping allows you to catch the seeds while preventing the birds from eating them. Dry off the plant. Sunflower seeds may be dried in the sun or in a dehydrator at 100 °F (38 °C). Higher temperatures affect the flavor, so keep it low. Roast the seeds. When the seeds are dried, they can be roasted in a shallow pan at 300 °F (149 °C) for 10 to 15 minutes. See further How to dry and season raw sunflower seeds. Finished.
